statement:
Every doubly transitive group is .

Let $G$ acting on $X$ be doubly transitive. To show the action is , we
must show that all blocks are trivial blocks; to do this, it suffices to
show that any block containing more than one element is all of $X$. So
choose a block $Y$ with two distinct elements $y_1, y_2$. Given an
arbitrary $x\in X$, since $G$ is doubly transitive, we can choose
$\sigma\in G$ such that $$\sigma\cdot(y_1,y_2)=(y_1,x)$$ But then
$\sigma\cdot Y\cap Y\neq\emptyset$, since $y_1$ is in both. Thus
$\sigma\cdot Y=Y$, so $x\in Y$ as well. So $Y=X$ and we are done.
